awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Small molecule regulation of plant autophagy and the biochemical characterization of whole intact autophagosomes
awd_abstract_narration: Autophagy, the regulated degradation and recycling of cellular material, is required for many cellular functions including the response to starvation, differentiation and development and senescence and immunity. However, the regulation of this process and the structure of the autophagosome (the organelle in which autophagy occurs) are not well understood in plants. This project will advance our understanding of autophagy in plants (specifically Arabidopsis) by addressing two major unsolved challenges 1) developing high-throughput assays to identify small chemical modulators of autophagy in plants, and 2) developing methods for the biochemical purification and study of plant autophagosomes. Broader Impacts. Training at the intersection of proteomics, biochemistry, cell biology and chemical genomics will be provided to a postdoctoral fellow and to undergraduate students.

por.por_cntn:
Project outcome report

Macroautophagy, here after referred to as autophagy, is a dynamic process that is conserved across eukaryotes and entails the engulfment of cellular components in double membrane vesicles called autophagosomes. Autophagosomes are then targeted to the vacuole/lysosome for degradation or recycling. Autophagy is a tightly regulated process and failure to activate or shut off autophagy in a timely fashion will have a deleterious effect on the organism. In this project, we developed novel Atg8 synthetic substrates (Atg8-SS) to monitor Atg4-mediated processing and autophagy in plants. Our results indicate that AtAtg4a functions predominantly to generate mature AtAtg8 isoforms. In addition, AtAtg4b-mediated differential cleavage of AtAtg8s suggests possible non-redundant roles for some AtAtg8s in vivo. Our in vivo data in transgenic Arabidopsis plants expressing Atg8-SS showed that the synthetic substrates are efficiently cleaved by endogenous AtAtg4s to activate autophagy in plants.

The Atg8-SS that we have developed could be used to monitor cleavage of AtAtg8s by AtAtg4s and autophagy using BRET-based assays. We have used BRET-based assay followed by in vitro cleavage assay in a high throughput screening to identify novel chemicals that activate or inhibit autophagy in plant cells. To identify cargoes carried by autophagosomes, we have optimized methods for isolation of intact autophagosomes from plant cells. The results generated from this project will facilitate to understand the role of autophagy in various biological processes.

Broader Impact: The project has provided training to a post-doctoral fellow. The project has provided training to three undergraduate students and a 10 week training for a minority student from Sacramento City College.
